title: AB 1534
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature emphasizes the importance of county assessors following state laws for consistent and accurate property assessments, ensuring decisions on property exemptions and ownership changes are made by certified staff to protect taxpayers' interests. The Legislature emphasizes efficient implementation of education and certification requirements for county assessors, utilizing existing resources. Contracts for outside appraisal work must be competitively bid on a fixed fee or hourly rate basis. A contractor must maintain the confidentiality of assessee information as required by specific sections of the law. Requests for information from an assessee must be made by the assessor, who may authorize the contractor to request additional information with written permission. A contractor must not share appraisal data with assessors from other counties. They must also return and purge any confidential information obtained from an assessee within 90 days of contract conclusion. A contractor must return and purge any assessee records provided by the assessor, and provide a written declaration of compliance. Contracts must include provisions prescribed by the State Board of Equalization. A contractor is defined as a person not employed by the state, county, or city who performs appraisal work under contract with an assessor. An assessor or county assessor employee must hold an assessment analyst certificate to make decisions on changes in ownership. A contractor, defined as a person not employed by the state, county, or city, must return assessee records and provide a compliance declaration. Assessors or county assessor employees must have an assessment analyst certificate to make decisions on changes in ownership and property tax exemptions, excluding homeowners' exemption claims. The board administers examinations for assessment analyst certificates, in collaboration with the Department of Human Resources. Exams are prepared by the board with input from a committee of assessors. Certificates are only issued to those who pass the exam and demonstrate competency in making ownership change or exemption decisions as defined by board regulations. The county assessor must pass an examination and demonstrate competency in making ownership change or exemption decisions as defined by board regulations. Applicants denied a certificate have the right to a review under the Administrative Procedure Act. The board does not charge fees for examinations or training for assessors holding valid certificates. Certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually to maintain their certificate. Certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually to maintain their certificate. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation following the Administrative Procedure Act. Carryover training hours are allowed for up to three years. The board requires certified assessment analysts to undergo annual training on new legal developments. An advanced assessment analyst certificate can be obtained after holding a certificate for three years and completing an advanced course or passing an advanced level examination. The board, with the help of assessors, prescribes the course of study and prepares the examination. To maintain a valid advanced assessment analyst certificate, holders must complete 12 hours of training annually. Any excess training time can be carried over for future requirements, up to a maximum of two years. The board, with the assistance of assessors, designs an advanced course of study and administers the advanced level examination. Failure to complete training for the advanced assessment analyst certificate may result in revocation. Excess training time can be carried over for future requirements, up to a maximum of two years. Revocation proceedings will follow the Administrative Procedure Act. Training for the advanced assessment analyst certificate includes updates on case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Duplicate filings with the Fair Political Practices Commission may fulfill this requirement. The board may issue a temporary certificate to newly elected or appointed assessors or newly employed individuals in the county assessor's office for up to one year to allow them to take an examination. Temporary certificates will not be renewed. The board may issue an interim certificate to current assessors or employees in the county assessor's office to allow them to apply for and take an examination. The interim certificate cannot exceed four years unless the person is duly elected or appointed as assessor, and it cannot be renewed. This article allows assessors to efficiently manage staff resources for exemption applications and change in ownership documents, as long as noncertificated staff do not make decisions. It applies only in counties that have passed a resolution requiring certification.
